name: Jack Travis
content:
Jack Travis (born March 2, 1952) is an American interior designer, architect, author and educator based in South Bronx, New York City. He designed Spike Lee's home and was the architectural consultant for Lee's film Jungle Fever.[1]  He has mentored students at the Charter High School for Architecture.[2] Travis wrote African American Architects in Current Practice (1991) [3]
 
 This article about a United States architect or architectural firm is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.
raw:
for the cartoon character see Goldie Gold and Action Jack
American architect
Jack Travis (born March 2, 1952) is an American interior designer, architect, author and educator based in South Bronx, New York City. He designed Spike Lee's home and was the architectural consultant for Lee's film Jungle Fever.[1]  He has mentored students at the Charter High School for Architecture.[2] Travis wrote African American Architects in Current Practice (1991) [3]

References[edit]


^ Kahn, Eve (April 9, 1992). "Renewed Hope For Black Architects". NY Times. Retrieved 18 February 2010.

^ [1] Ebony 2005 page 114

^ Andy Pressman Curing the fountainheadache: how architects & their clients communicate pages 120-124
